message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
public class Overview {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws FileNotFoundException {
        // TODO code application logic here
        int count = 0;
        double totalCost=0.00;
        ArrayList<Double> propertyCosts = new ArrayList<>();
        //Get file name
        Scanner console = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.print ("Please enter file name: ");
        String inputFileName = console.next();
        File inputFile = new File(inputFileName);
        // Get the object of DataInputStream
        FileInputStream fstream = new FileInputStream(inputFile);
        DataInputStream in = new DataInputStream(fstream);
        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(in));
        String line;
        try {
            while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
                StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(line, " ");
                st.nextToken(); // Skip PropertyID
                st.nextToken(); // Skip Type
                double cost = Double.parseDouble(st.nextToken()); // Get Cost
                propertyCosts.add(cost);
                totalCost += cost;
                count++;
            }
        } catch(Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        } finally {
            System.out.println("Total properties in list: " + count + "\n"+ "The total cost is: " +totalCost);
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we use StringTokenizer to split each line by spaces. We then call nextToken() twice to skip the first two fields (PropertyID and Type). We then call nextToken() a third time to get the Cost field, which we parse as a double and add to the totalCost. We also add this cost to the propertyCosts ArrayList. We increment the count each time we successfully parse a line. At the end, we print out the total number of properties and the total cost.
